summary: So, I read somewhere that GRRM believes that Sansa had a part in what happened to Ned, and I'm wondering...where? Because I...
question: So, I read somewhere that GRRM believes that Sansa had a part in what happened to Ned, and I'm wondering...where? Because I don't see at all how she had anything to do with Ned being imprisoned or him dying.
answer: She didn’t. In both the books and show, Cersei was already moving against Ned. He died because he made a series of mistakes based on his honor rather than cunning. At the very best, Sansa gave Cersei a timeline of when Ned expected them to leave the city and when he felt he could use force. GRRM made sure Ned told Sansa nothing and yet he wants to insist Sansa had a part in Ned’ death. Unless that part is Ned confessing to treason to save her life I will need GRRM to reread his books.

summary: Hi, i’ve read your fix ‘there is no turning back ‘( great fic btw) and in ur fic Sansa and Jaime talk about elia martell and...
question: Hi, i’ve read your fix ‘there is no turning back ‘( great fic btw) and in ur fic Sansa and Jaime talk about elia martell and that jaime thinks elia was a saint. Jaime’s relationship with tywin is also a complex part of the story and i wonder how you think jaime felt about elia’s rape and murder on tywin’s orders. I love all your fics and i hope you will keep writing! ❤️
answer:
Hey, anon! I’m so happy you’re enjoying TINTB, thank you for the compliment! How does Jaime feel about the way Elia was raped and killed so violently? Well, I think he was absolutely horrified by it, and wishes he could have stopped it - but he was in the Throne Room with Aerys at the time, so he didn’t know it was happening. There’s a fair amount of survivor’s guilt there. As regards Jaime’s feelings for his father - majorly, majorly complicated. Such a mess. It is something that will be addressed in an upcoming chapter, hopefully in a way that will be satisfying to read. 

thank you!

summary: Am I the only one who felt annoyed at how Jon responded to Sansa about being smarter? I dunno, just the way he said "how should...
question: Am I the only one who felt annoyed at how Jon responded to Sansa about being smarter? I dunno, just the way he said "how should I be smarter, by listening to YOU?" sounded really condescending. Like it was unthinkable to take council from Sansa at all. I'd think it perhaps an acting choice, if not for the fact that Jon later refuses to take council from her even after this moment, and that Sansa laments that he's never asked her opinion before, so why would he start now, when he bent to Dany.
answer:
No you’re not the only one. Such a bitchy comment like Sansa was beneath him. The fact that moments later he accuses Sansa of admiring Cersei like Sansa wasn’t held hostage by her. Maybe if he’s ‘lowered’ himself and listened to Sansa he’d know Cersei was too smart to send what little army she has left north. Not only that, if he ever faces consequences for kneeling, I doubt he’d have a single moment of ‘I should have asked/warned you beforehand’ because of this scene. I know some people say he craves Sansa’s approval but I disagree. Sansa had to go behind his back to contact Littlefinger because he wouldn’t listen, she disagreed with his Umber-Karstark ruling with valid reason and he accuses her of undermining him, he never discusses anything with her and still expects her to do all the work as Lady of Winterfell.

Now I want a fic in which she’s crowned Queen.

tags: one day i will write out that elder brother therapy fic
summary: Does Clegane believe Sansa killed Joffrey? He knew Sansa wanted Joff dead. And if so, would it matter to him at all?
question: Does Clegane believe Sansa killed Joffrey? He knew Sansa wanted Joff dead. And if so, would it matter to him at all?
answer:
I’m afraid we don’t know what Sandor thinks about Joffrey’s murder, because he was remarkably distracted by how the information was presented to him. (Text follows, Arya’s internal narrative removed for clarity)

“King Joffrey’s dead, you know,” he added. “Poisoned at his own wedding feast.”
“So much for my brave brothers of the Kingsguard.” The Hound gave a snort of contempt. “Who killed him?”
“The Imp, it’s thought. Him and his little wife.”
“What wife?”
“I forgot, you’ve been hiding under a rock. The northern girl. Winterfell’s daughter. We heard she killed the king with a spell, and afterward changed into a wolf with big leather wings like a bat, and flew out a tower window. But she left the dwarf behind and Cersei means to have his head.”
The Hound sat on the bench closest to the door. His mouth twitched, but only the burned side. “She ought to dip him in wildfire and cook him. Or tickle him till the moon turns black.” He raised his wine cup and drained it straightaway.
[…]
The Hound poured a cup of wine for Arya and another for himself, and drank it down while staring at the hearthfire. “The little bird flew away, did she? Well, bloody good for her. She shit on the Imp’s head and flew off.”

–ASOS, Arya XIII

So, Sandor hears Joffrey’s dead, hears that Tyrion and his wife Sansa are accused of the murder, and the next thing he does is drink two whole cups of wine, talk about how Tyrion should die, and stare at the fire. Oh, and talk about how good it is that Sansa escaped. (And then later, when he’s in pain and feverish and wanting to die, his regrets are all about Sansa (and Tyrion), he doesn’t mention Joffrey at all.)

Frankly, I think as soon as Sandor heard Sansa was married to Tyrion, he stopped even thinking about Joffrey’s murder. All he could do was imagine the terrible things that marriage would involve, and be glad she escaped from them. Sandor’s focus is so much about Sansa’s marriage, that what happened to Joffrey and who was to blame just doesn’t matter anymore.

She wondered what had become of Sandor Clegane. Did he know that they’d killed Joffrey? Would he care? He had been the prince’s sworn shield for years. –ASOS, Sansa VI

And as for Sansa’s concerns – and imagining if the info about the murder had been presented in a less distracting way – I believe that once Joffrey lost Sandor’s loyalty, that no, he doesn’t care about him either.

But I suppose, say the Elder Brother is doing some talk therapy with a recovering Sandor on the Quiet Isle, who’s had more time to think about what he’s heard (and dwell on it, and dwell on it some more)… and the Elder Brother asks him if he thinks if the rumors about the murder are true… Well, first, Sandor knows Sansa’s no sorceress, so the spell thing is obviously false. If the info from the trial regarding poisons has reached them, yeah, I’m pretty sure Sandor knows Sansa enough to believe she’d never premeditatively poison anyone either, even Joffrey. A crime of passion, like how she nearly pushed Joffrey off the bridge, that he could believe she’d do, sure. But since that’s not how Joff died, nah, it’s the dwarf that did it, not the little bird.

I hope that helps!
